line: Produced by Ben Courtney, Suzanne Shell and the Online
And asked his way to Norwich;
To market, to market, to buy a fat Pig;
Home again, home again, dancing a jig.
To market, to market, to buy a fat Hog;
There was a man, and he had nought,
And robbers came to rob him;
He crept up to the chimney-pot,
And then they thought they had him;
But he got down on t'other side,
And then they could not find him;
He ran fourteen miles in fifteen days,
And sent them out of town.
_Gay go up, and gay go down
To ring the bells of London Town._
Say the bells of St. Marg'ret's.
Say the bells of St. Giles'.
Say the bells of St. Peter's.
Say the bells of St. Martin's.
Say the bells of St. Clement's.
Say the slow bells at Aldgate.
Say the bells of St. John's.
Say the bells of St. Ann's.
Say the bells at St. Helen's.
Say the bells at Old Bailey.
I am sure I don't know,
Says the great bell of Bow.
_Here comes a candle to light you to bed,
And here comes a chopper to chop off your head._
There I met an old man
That would not say his prayers:
I took him by the left leg,
Humpty Dumpty sat on a wall;
Humpty Dumpty had a great fall;
All the King's horses and all the King's men
Couldn't put Humpty Dumpty together again.
And one for the little boy

line: Jack and Jill went up the hill
To fetch a pail of water;
Jack fell down and broke his crown,
Says Simple Simon to the pieman,
Says the pieman to Simple Simon,
Says Simon, "Yes, of course I do!"
All the water he had got
There was a crooked man, and he went a crooked mile,
He found a crooked sixpence against a crooked stile:
He bought a crooked cat, which caught a crooked mouse,
And they all lived together in a crooked little house.
Little Bo-Peep has lost her sheep,
And can't tell where to find them;
Leave them alone, and they'll come home,
And bring their tails behind them.
And dreamt she heard them bleating;
But when she awoke, she found it a joke,
Then up she took her little crook,
She found them indeed, but it made her heart bleed,
For they'd left all their tails behind 'em.
And he had a little gun,
And his bullets were made of lead, lead, lead;
And he shot it right through the head, head, head.
And bid her a fire for to make, make, make;
He had shot in the brook,
And he'd go and fetch her the drake, drake, drake.
When good king Arthur ruled this land,
He stole three pecks of barley-meal,
A bag-pudding the king did make,
And stuffed it well with plums;
And in it put great lumps of fat,
As big as my two thumbs.
The king and queen did eat thereof,
And what they could not eat that night,
To see what my black hen doth lay.
My dame has lost her shoe;
And don't know what to do.
What is my dame to do?
My dame has lost her shoe,
My dame will dance with you,
Gone to bed and scratched her head,
And can't tell what to do.
Wee Willie Winkie runs through the town,
Upstairs and downstairs in his nightgown,
Rapping at the window, crying through the lock,
"Are the children in their beds, for now it's eight o'clock?"
